io.spine.server.procman

Class ProcessManager<I,S extends com.google.protobuf.Message,B extends io.spine.validate.ValidatingBuilder<S,? extends com.google.protobuf.Message.Builder>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.spine.server.entity.AbstractEntity<I,S>
      • io.spine.server.entity.AbstractVersionableEntity<I,S>
        • io.spine.server.entity.TransactionalEntity<I,S,B>
          • io.spine.server.command.CommandHandlingEntity<I,S,B>
            • io.spine.server.procman.ProcessManager<I,S,B>
  • Type Parameters:
    I - the type of the process manager IDs
    S - the type of the process manager state
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Commander, CommandHandler, CommandReceiver, Entity<I,S>, EntityWithLifecycle<I,S>, VersionableEntity<I,S>, EventReactor, EventReceiver, EventProducer

    public abstract class ProcessManager<I,S extends com.google.protobuf.Message,B extends io.spine.validate.ValidatingBuilder<S,? extends com.google.protobuf.Message.Builder>>
extends CommandHandlingEntity<I,S,B>
implements EventReactor, Commander
    A central processing unit used to maintain the state of the business process and determine the next processing step based on intermediate results.

    A process manager reacts to domain events in a cross-aggregate, eventually consistent manner.

    Event and command handlers are invoked by the ProcessManagerRepository that manages instances of a process manager class.

    For more information on Process Managers, please see:

    • Process Manager Pattern
    • Clarifying the Saga pattern â€” the difference between Process Manager and Saga
    • Are Sagas and Workflows the same...
    • CQRS Journey Guide: A Saga on Sagas

      • getBuilder

        protected B getBuilder()
        Obtains the instance of the state builder.

        This method must be called only from within an active transaction.

        In ProcessManager, this method must be called from an event reactor, a rejection reactor, or a command handler.
